Sai Prakash
Projects Bookmarks Now Photos

Rivers are now battlefields

February 2024

6 min read

As someone who watches global infrastructure development, I’m occasionally asked if water will become a weapon. It already is. Specifically, China has built hundreds of dams on rivers that flow into other countries—giving Beijing control over water resources that billions of people depend on.

Major rivers originating in the Tibetan Plateau flow through multiple countries in South and Southeast Asia. The Mekong flows through Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, and Thailand. The Brahmaputra through India and Bangladesh. The Indus through Pakistan and India. Over 2 billion people depend on water from rivers that originate in Chinese-controlled territory.

China’s massive dam-building program on these rivers gives it unprecedented leverage. Unlike traditional military conflicts, water wars are fought through infrastructure—dams that can regulate, redirect, or withhold the lifeblood of downstream nations. The power is subtle but absolute: control the water, and you control agriculture, industry, and ultimately, political stability.

But there’s a potential escape route: solar-powered desalination. If downstream nations can produce their own freshwater from seawater, China’s upstream control loses much of its strategic value. The technology is improving rapidly, and costs are dropping. The question is whether affected nations will invest in water independence before the leverage becomes unbearable.

The Tibetan water tower

The Tibetan Plateau is often called the “Water Tower of Asia” because it’s the source of most major rivers in South and Southeast Asia. This gives China extraordinary strategic advantage—not through military force, but through geography and infrastructure.

The dependency creates multiple vulnerabilities for downstream nations. Irrigation systems designed around predictable river flows can fail when upstream dams alter water release patterns. Water can be used as a bargaining chip in diplomatic negotiations. And historically, competition over scarce water resources has led to tension and warfare.

This isn’t theoretical. During the 2019 drought, satellite data showed China holding back water on the Mekong while downstream countries faced their worst drought in decades. Rice harvests failed. Fish populations—critical for protein in the region—collapsed. The economic and human costs were enormous.

China’s construction campaign

China has built or is planning hundreds of dams on transboundary rivers. The Three Gorges Dam is the world’s largest hydroelectric power station. Eleven dams are operational or under construction on the upper Mekong. Planned projects on the Brahmaputra could generate three times the power of Three Gorges.

These dams serve multiple purposes beyond power generation: energy security for China’s growing economy, flood control protecting Chinese territory, political leverage over downstream nations, and economic development in western China.

For China, this makes perfect sense. For downstream nations, it’s an existential threat wrapped in infrastructure development.

The alternative

Solar-powered desalination could provide an escape route. By converting seawater to freshwater using renewable energy, coastal nations could secure their water supplies without relying on rivers controlled by other countries.

The advantages are clear. It removes dependence on upstream water control. It uses sustainable energy with no fuel imports required. It’s scalable—you can start small and expand as needed. And many vulnerable populations already live near coastlines where desalination plants can be built.

The challenges are equally clear. Large-scale desalination plants require substantial upfront investment. Concentrated salt byproduct must be safely managed to avoid environmental damage. Meeting the water needs of millions requires massive facilities. Getting water from coast to inland agricultural areas requires extensive pipeline networks. And solar power varies with weather and time of day, requiring storage solutions.

The technology is improving

Several developments are making solar desalination more practical. Modern solar panels convert 20-25% of sunlight to electricity, and costs have dropped 90% in the past decade. New reverse osmosis membranes require less pressure (and thus less energy), with higher flow rates and better resistance to fouling. Energy recovery systems can capture up to 60% of energy used in desalination. And modular desalination units can be deployed rapidly with lower upfront capital requirements.

The economics are becoming increasingly favorable. A decade ago, solar desalination was prohibitively expensive. Today, it’s approaching cost-competitiveness with conventional water sources in some regions. As technology continues to improve and scale increases, costs will continue to fall.

Proof of concept

Israel provides a working example. The country now produces 80% of its domestic water through desalination, making it essentially water-independent. Large facilities like the Sorek plant produce water at costs competitive with conventional sources.

Saudi Arabia operates the world’s largest desalination capacity, producing over 5 million cubic meters per day. The country is increasingly coupling desalination with solar power to reduce costs and environmental impact.

These examples show that the technology works at scale. The question isn’t whether it’s possible, but whether downstream nations facing water insecurity will make the necessary investments.

Shifting power dynamics

If downstream nations can meet their water needs through desalination, upstream control of rivers loses much of its strategic value. This could be one of the most significant geopolitical shifts in Asia in coming decades.

Water disputes become less existential when alternatives exist. Upstream dams lose power as bargaining chips. Nations can build population centers and industries without river access. Coastal farming becomes viable, reducing dependence on river irrigation. And countries become less vulnerable to drought and changing precipitation patterns.

The path isn’t simple. Political obstacles exist—existing water infrastructure creates entrenched interests. Not all countries have the technical capacity to deploy and maintain facilities. Cross-border water sharing treaties may need renegotiation. Local opposition to coastal desalination plants must be addressed. And getting water to inland farms remains challenging.

A realistic timeline

The key question is whether solar desalination can scale fast enough and cheaply enough to provide a genuine alternative to river water for hundreds of millions of people.

An optimistic scenario: Continued cost declines, government commitment, and international support enable rapid deployment. Vietnam, Bangladesh, and Pakistan achieve significant water independence within 20 years.

A pessimistic scenario: High capital costs, political inertia, and technical challenges slow deployment. Solar desalination remains a niche solution, and upstream control of rivers continues to shape regional politics.

The most likely outcome: Partial deployment provides meaningful alternatives for urban and some industrial uses, reducing but not eliminating dependence on transboundary rivers. This still represents a significant shift in the balance of power.

The role of international support

Development banks and wealthy nations could accelerate deployment through concessional financing for infrastructure, technical assistance and capacity building, research and development support, and diplomatic pressure for water-sharing agreements.

For downstream nations, the path forward is clear: start planning now, as large-scale desalination infrastructure takes years to deploy. Build technical capacity by training engineers and developing operational expertise. Seek international support to leverage development financing. Run pilot projects first to demonstrate viability before committing to massive investments. And address environmental concerns by developing sustainable brine management solutions.

The rivers of Asia will continue to flow from the Tibetan Plateau. But they don’t have to determine the fate of billions. Technology—if deployed with vision and commitment—can write a different future. The question isn’t whether technology can free nations from water dependence. It’s whether they’ll invest in freedom before the leverage becomes unbearable.
